SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “parched” as it is used in paragraph 4?

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 8.
:ibox:Their orange-and-black wings color the sky like an explosion of confetti.
What is the author's MAIN purpose for using this sentence?

A.Choice: to describe a feeling of excitement while watching butterflies

B.Choice: to indicate the direction the butterflies will go as they travel

C.Choice: to describe the large number of butterflies taking flight

D.Choice: to indicate the distance the butterflies will need to travel

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the development of an argument and specific claims in texts, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and relevant evidence from claims that are not.
Content: Which sentence from the article BEST supports the author's central claim?

A.Choice: “The sun—its rise and fall over a day and the whirling of the Earth around it for a year— powers these events.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Like the region's other hoofed animals—wildebeests and gazelles—zebras must stay on the move for fresh grass and water.” (paragraph 16)

C.Choice: “Sometimes, herds will come together by the thousands to find better feeding grounds.” (paragraph 17)

D.Choice: “The timing of their travels is driven by rainfall, which fuels the growth of new grass and refills water holes.” (paragraph 19)

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify the point of view and explain how it is developed and conveys meaning. In informational texts, explain how an author's geographic location or culture affects his or her perspective.
Content: Which detail from the article represents the author's belief?

A.Choice: “They are some of nature's most thrilling dramas.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “... forgetting the location of a lifesaving water hole would be a deadly mistake.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “... these jellyfish undertake a major journey every single day.” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “Human babies can take a year or more to take their first steps.” (paragraph 21)

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: According to the article, zebras and wildebeests are similar because both animals

D.Choice: eat the same type of grass

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, stanza, chapter, scene, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and how it contributes to the development of theme, central idea, setting, or plot. In informational texts, analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and how it contributes to the development of theme or central ideas.
Content: The main way the different “Motive to Move” sections help the reader understand migration is by

A.Choice: explaining why animals search for watering holes

B.Choice: referring to areas where there is a lack of grass

C.Choice: explaining why animals travel to different places

D.Choice: referring to seasons that change from dry to rainy

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: Which phrase from the article BEST helps the reader understand the claim in paragraph 22 that “being in a rush is a way of life” for wildebeests?

A.Choice: the reference to the wildebeest being “a favorite snack” (paragraph 22)

B.Choice: the indication that wildebeests follow “the seasonal rains” (paragraph 22)

C.Choice: the explanation that plant eaters like the wildebeest “stay on the move” (paragraph 23)

D.Choice: the claim that wildebeests would “starve if they didn't migrate” (paragraph 23)

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: According to the article, what was the MAIN effect of Franklin's study of static electricity?

A.Choice: the ability to generate static electricity to study it

B.Choice: the understanding that static electricity resembled lightning

C.Choice: the realization that lightning was larger than static electricity

D.Choice: the creation of a tool to prevent lightning from harming people

SubTopics: Use established criteria in order to evaluate the quality of texts. Make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, and personal experiences.
Content: Working with electricity can sometimes be dangerous. Which detail in the article BEST supports this idea?

A.Choice: the claim that sharks “can sense electric signals” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: the statement that “Lightning often hit tall buildings” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: the claim that a battery uses “metal and chemicals to create electrical energy” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: the statement that many objects used for light “were smelly and caused fires” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is developed by key supporting details over the course of a text; summarize a text.
Content: In paragraph 14, how does the author demonstrate how the demand for electricity “caught on”?

A.Choice: by highlighting important scientists who studied electricity

B.Choice: by including dates and descriptions of major discoveries

C.Choice: by suggesting that people began to appreciate and use electricity

D.Choice: by indicating that certain inventions helped people remain safe

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify the point of view and explain how it is developed and conveys meaning. In informational texts, explain how an author's geographic location or culture affects his or her perspective.
Content: What is MOST LIKELY the author's opinion about electricity?

A.Choice: Electricity should continue to be studied by scientists and inventors.

B.Choice: Electricity was made popular as the result of the electric motor.

C.Choice: Electricity was not useful until energy could travel longer distances.

D.Choice: Electricity is an important and essential part of people's lives.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, stanza, chapter, scene, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and how it contributes to the development of theme, central idea, setting, or plot. In informational texts, analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and how it contributes to the development of theme or central ideas.
Content: How does the author organize information to develop a central idea in the article?

A.Choice: by contrasting the different scientists who studied electricity

B.Choice: by providing details about the development of electricity in chronological order

C.Choice: by explaining how electricity helped solve a variety of problems

D.Choice: by using a cause and effect structure to highlight the significance of electricity

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the development of an argument and specific claims in texts, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and relevant evidence from claims that are not.
Content: In “Excerpt from The Story Behind Electricity,” how does the author support the claim that electricity has become “more and more a part of our lives” (paragraph 4)? Use TWO details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, stanza, chapter, scene, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and how it contributes to the development of theme, central idea, setting, or plot. Content: In “Excerpt from The Story Behind Electricity,” how are the ideas in paragraphs 8 and 9 related? Use TWO details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: In paragraph 2, the author uses the phrase “in a foreign tongue” to indicate that Mate

A.Choice: only responds to the commands of Charlie

B.Choice: dislikes being patted by the townspeople

C.Choice: does not want to stop his walk with Charlie

D.Choice: does not care what the townspeople say

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: Which detail signals a change in the direction of the story?

A.Choice: the indication that Mate listened “with his head cocked to one side and one ear raised” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: the statement that “Mate would bark loudly, acting as the Fast and Able's foghorn” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: the indication that “Charlie fell to the bottom of the boat unconscious” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: the statement that “Mate leaped into the cold water and dog-paddled to the beach” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 5.
:ibox:Mate whimpered and frantically licked his master's face, but the old seaman did not move.
The words “whimpered” and “frantically” affect the tone of the story by

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: How does paragraph 8 BEST help advance the plot of the story?

A.Choice: by showing that Jake knows Charlie's dog

B.Choice: by demonstrating how Mate responds to Jake's voice

C.Choice: by having Jake realize Charlie may be in trouble

D.Choice: by illustrating the trust Jake inspires in Mate

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: What do the details in paragraphs 9 through 11 MAINLY reveal about Mate?

A.Choice: He is popular in the town.

B.Choice: He cares deeply about his master.

C.Choice: He knows how to save lives.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: Which detail BEST shows how the author indicates the close friendship of Charlie and Mate to the reader?

A.Choice: “Sailing in each other's company provided a perfect afternoon for Charlie and Mate,” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “Mate either slept on the sun-warmed deck or joined Charlie in the cockpit,” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “The cold seawater flew off Mate's furry coat and splashed over Charlie,” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “Charlie softly whispered, 'Shipshape!' to Mate, then a little louder, 'Hardtack!'” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Use established criteria in order to evaluate the quality of texts. Make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, and personal experiences.
Content: A common saying is that “Dogs are man's best friend.” Which detail from the story BEST supports this idea?

A.Choice: Mate responds to words Charlie teaches him.

B.Choice: Mate walks with Charlie when they are in town.

C.Choice: Mate sleeps in the boat when Charlie is sailing.

D.Choice: Mate leaves the boat to get help for Charlie.

Content: In “Excerpt from Radio Girl,” how do paragraphs 3 and 4 contribute to the story's structure? Use TWO details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 6 of “Excerpt from Manhattan Transfer: A Novel.”
:ibox:A trembling took hold of his knees.
What effect does this sentence have on the tone of the story? Use TWO details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe how events unfold, as well as how characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: In “Excerpt from Manhattan Transfer: A Novel,” why does Bud continue on his journey to New York City even though he is exhausted? Use TWO details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is developed by key supporting details over the course of a text; summarize a text.
Content: The stories “Excerpt from Radio Girl” and “Excerpt from Manhattan Transfer: A Novel” both share a similar theme. What is the similar theme in both stories? How does each author develop this theme differently? Use details from BOTH stories to support your response.
In your response, be sure to

:ibox:• identify a similar theme shared by both stories
• explain how each author develops this theme differently
• use details from BOTH stories to support your response
